title: R43770
content: The aiding and abetting subsection of 18 U.S.C. 2 holds individuals accountable for assisting in the commission of a federal crime. It requires the defendant to actively contribute to the success of another's crime by associating themselves with the venture and seeking to make it succeed. Aiding and abetting involves actively contributing to the success of another's crime by associating with the venture and seeking to make it succeed. The defendant must know the offense is happening before it occurs to be convicted. The quantity of assistance is immaterial as long as the accomplice aids the crime. Knowledge without assistance or assistance without intent is not enough. A federal offense must be committed by someone else for aiding and abetting to apply. The quantity of assistance is immaterial as long as the accomplice aids the crime under §2. A completed offense is a prerequisite for aiding and abetting conviction, with the defendant's involvement needing to occur before or at the time of the offense. Assistance given after the crime is a separate offense as an accessory after the fact. The defendant's aiding and abetting must occur before or at the time of the offense, as assistance given after the crime is a separate offense. Accomplices may sometimes avoid federal principles of secondary criminal liability, especially when there is a substantial culpability gap. Accomplices can be victims, customers, or subordinates, with not every victim qualifying for an exception based on culpability. For example, a victim involved in a scheme to corrupt a public official may be convicted as an accomplice to extortion. Some victims may not qualify for exceptions based on culpability, such as those involved in schemes to corrupt public officials. Customers like drinkers, bettors, johns, and drug addicts have escaped conviction as co-conspirators. Supreme Court cases like United States v. Farrar and Rewis v. United States have ruled that mere bettors cannot be prosecuted for aiding and abetting illegal activities. The Court ruled that mere bettors cannot be prosecuted for aiding and abetting illegal activities, including interstate travel in aid of unlawful gambling. The federal Controlled Substances Act reinforces the view that a drug trafficker's customers cannot be prosecuted as coconspirators or aiders and abettors. The law punishes traffickers severely but customers for simply possession. "Subordinates" face more difficulty in avoiding secondary liability. The Supreme Court ruled in Gebardi that a woman transported for immoral purposes could not be charged with conspiracy under the Mann Act. Lower courts followed this ruling but limited it to cases where the prostitute only acquiesced to transportation. Employees of an OSHA offender cannot be prosecuted as aiders and abettors. Subordinates of offenders under the federal gambling business statute can be prosecuted. There is no consensus on how subordinates of a drug kingpin may be treated. The federal gambling business statute condemns those who supervise an unlawful gambling enterprise involving five or more individuals. There is no consensus on how subordinates of a drug kingpin may be treated. Section 2(b) applies to defendants who work through intermediaries, whether witting or unwitting, guilty or innocent. The intermediary's awareness of their conduct does not affect the application of the law. Section 2(b) applies to defendants who work through intermediaries, whether aware or unaware of their conduct. The intermediary's awareness does not affect the law's application. The amendment in 1951 added "willfully causes" without clear purpose, possibly to address a lack of mental element in §2(b). The word "willfully" was added to address a lack of mental element in §2(b). Courts understand "willfully" to mean intentionally causing an offense through someone else. Liability can be incurred under §2(b) even if the individual is unaware the conduct is a crime. Federal courts mention a withdrawal defense similar to conspiracy cases, where withdrawal is not a defense for conspiracy itself but for crimes committed after withdrawal. In conspiracy, withdrawal is not a defense for conspiracy itself but only for crimes committed in foreseeable furtherance of the scheme after the defendant's withdrawal. The defendant must demonstrate affirmative action to withdraw, such as informing authorities or coconspirators. In aiding and abetting, withdrawal defense in federal cases may be limited, with liability not incurred if the underlying offense is not committed due to withdrawal of assistance. The question of withdrawal from aiding and abetting a crime is unsettled, with varying results in different courts. Proponents of a general withdrawal defense may find support in recent dicta in Rosemond, where the Supreme Court suggested that an accomplice might be able to withdraw and escape liability prior to the commission of the substantive offense. Courts have determined that aiders and abettors do not face civil liability for their involvement in various offenses such as violations of the Anti-Terrorism Act, Electronic Communications Privacy Act, Stored Communications Act, or RICO.
